titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p: 1. IV:30. Thursday— New-Year— Drawing Room—

The year begins in gloom— My wife had a sleepless and painful Night—The dawn was overcast; and as I began to write my shaded lamp went out, self-extinguished; it was only for lack of Oil; and the notice of so trivial an incident may serve but to mark the present temper of my mind— But in every situation in which mortal man can be placed there is a line of conduct before him, which it is his duty to pursue; and the Season of Adversity, though depriving him of the means which in prosperity he may possess of doing good to his fellow men, is perhaps not less adapted to the exercise of virtues equally conducive to the dignity of human Nature— But in good or in evil fortune “It is not in Man that walketh to direct his steps”— Let him look to the fountain of all Good—let him consult the Oracles of God— I began the year with prayer—and then turning to my Bible read the first Psalm— It affirms that the righteous man is, and promises that he shall be blessed— This is comfort and Consolation—and points in general terms to the path of duty— May the light of this Lamp never forsake me!

Mr White the delegate from Florida, called and recommended Antonio Alvarez as keeper of the public Archives at St. Augustine— I had directed yesterday a Commission to issue to a Mr Sanchez but White says there are objections against him of which he was not informed when he assented to his appointment— I requested Mr D. Brent to have a Commission made out for Alvarez

A man named Matthew Dutton apparently insane brought me a long manuscript to consider, and will call again in two or three days. Our last New-Years Drawing-Room was crowded beyond all former example, and passed quietly off. From four to five I walked to the foot of College Hill and back; and witnessed the Cloudless setting of the Sun, with a feeling of hope and consolation— J. Sergeant and Johnson Hellen dined with us— My wife attended the Drawing-Room but was obliged to retire shortly after it was over to bed—
Ball at Mr Vaughan’s.
2. IV. Friday.— Snow— Walk round Capitol Square.

My wife was in excruciating pain the whole Night with inflammatory rhumatism— I was up between one and two in the Morning; and again at four— I then called up Susan the Housemaid, who roused John Kirke; and he went for the Dr Huntt.— He came about five and bled Mrs Adams after which she had some relief, but remained confined all day to her bed, with occasional severe returns of her complaint— There was a fall of Snow about six inches deep; which is more than has fallen at any one time these four years. Mr Brent called to ask the return of two Volumes of Records of the Senate, which he had borrowed some days since for me— And they were returned— Luther Thomas is a mendicant friar of the Free-Will Baptist Association, a subdivision of the Sect, with which I was not acquainted. He said they agreed with the Baptists in the principle of immersion, and with the Methodists in field preaching. Hiram Ariel Norris is a youth turned of 22. who solicits a warrant of Cadet at West-Point— He had letters of Recommendation from the Sculptor Frazee at New-York, whose pupil he has been— Mr Derrick brought me a Note from Baron Stackelberg Swedish charge d’Affaires complaining of the capture by Captain Turner in the Erie Sloop of War of a vessel in the harbour of St. Bartholomew, under a flag admitted there— It was a piratical vessel called the Federal— Mr Clay had prepared an answer to Baron Stackelberg promising enquiry and a Letter to the Secretary of the Navy requesting it, which I approved— Connell is here again from Philadelphia; going the first of February for Copenhagen upon the claims— General Parker came to recommend Dr Richard Harlan to go as naturalist on the exploring expedition, and to talk about General Scott. He had seen part of my Manuscript at the War Department, and asked Mercy for Scott. We had company to dine: Archer, Bailey. Beecher, W. L. Brent, Burnet, James Clark, Connell, Foot, Iredell, Leavenworth Lumpkin, Markell, Marks, Martindale, Mercer, O’Brien, Mr and Mrs Olney, Orr, Pierson, Storrs, Vance and L. and Mrs Woodbury— Message 12 to S.U.S. and 5. to H.R.U.S.
3. V. Saturday. Walk round Capitol Square

Mrs Adams had another painful and nearly sleepless Night and continues confined to her bed with an inflammatory rhumatic fever— I had a distracting succession of visitors. Mr Hooe came to solicit the clerkship vacant by the death of Mr Ramsay— But I had requested the Secretary of War to appoint Mr R. H. Lee— Mr. Taliaferro afterwards called and introduced another of his friends— Mr Gurley member of the House from Louisiana Mr Canfield of New Orleans— General Vance, member from Ohio. Mr Harland— Mr Ruggles, Senator from Ohio Mr Gordon of New-York Mr Lowrie the Secretary of the Senate, brought two Resolutions of the Senate, one confirming nominations; and the other calling for a Statement of Land-Office expenses in 1828— Mr Pearce the member from Rhode-Island, came with Mr Cahoone the applicant for a pursers appointment, and with B. Anthony whose reappointment as Marshal has been confirmed— Mr Iredell the new Senator and Mr Bryan member of the House from North-Carolina came to recommend H. G. Burton for Governor of the Territory of Arkansas. Mr Reed to introduce Mr Lincoln and Mr Folger, and to give me a Petition of Obed Baxter for a Pardon— Mr Silsbee and Mr Sprague of Maine had conversation separately with me upon an intrigue in the Senate to get C Hughes turned out as Minister to the Netherlands and W. P. Preble appointed in his place— I had requested to see Sprague also concerning the appointment of a Collector at Portland in the place of I. Ilsley, who declines a re-appointment. Major Nourse brought some copy from my Manuscript and I gave him the remainder— General Porter brought a Letter from W. Drayton Chairman of Military Committee H.R.U.S. with Reference of General Scott’s Memorial and Vance’s Resolution— Captain Coffin came for his papers and to take leave— Major Worth to ask promotion— I spoke to him of a late appeal by him to the public, by a printed circular, which I disapproved.
4. IV:45. Sunday.

Heard at the Unitarian Church Mr Bigelow, from 1. Corinthians 10.16. “The cup of blessing which we bless, is it not the communion of the blood of Christ? The bread which we break is it not the communion of the body of Christ?” After the Sermon, the Communion service was performed, in which I participated— There is always something eccentric in Mr Bigelow’s Discourses— This day he supposed on enquiry why the propagation of the gospel, had not been more extensively successful: and answered in substance that it was owing to the internal dissensions among Christians themselves— But the form in which he exhibited this thought was bitterly satyrical— He supposed an assemblage of Heathens willing to be converted to Christianity, and enquiring what they must do to be saved? And then he introduced a file of sectarians one after another, Roman Catholic, or Episcopalian, or Presbyterian, and a Baptist, succeeding each other upon the Scene, and each expounding the peculiar doctrines of his own Church, and making them ridiculous— In the afternoon I heard Mr Hawley at St. John’s— He read the abridged Evening Service, for the second Sunday after Christmas omitting the Psalms of the day and the Lesson from the Old Testament— He preached from Psalm 25.14. “The secret of the Lord is with them that fear him, and he will shew them his Covenant.” And he introduced his text with a very solemn admonition of the uncertainty of human life, and the moral certainty that of the very few of his hearers who had entered upon the new year there were some who before its close would be called to their great account— He gave out also to be sung the 129th Hymn—

So be it!— J. W. Taylor of New-York dined with us, and spent the Evening here— We had much political conversation— He is re-elected to the next Congress; but expressed some doubts whether he should come— He concurred with me that the two recent parties are both virtually dissolved— That of the Administration, irreversibly; and he Thinks Mr Clay never can take a lead in the affairs of the Nation— In this I differed from his opinion and reminded him of the sudden and total vicissitudes of De Witt Clinton’s popularity in New-York—
5. V. Monday
Pardon to Henry Reisner, convicted of stealing a Cow and a Bull— Circuit Court Washington County D.C.
Signed 776. Land grants
25. Blank Patents.
Commissions of Army Officers—

Mr Johnston Senator from Louisiana, urged the immediate nomination of a District Judge in the place of Thomas B. Robertson deceased— I said that Mr Gurley—the member of the House of Representatives had been recommended, and there would be some inconvenience in appointing him now, as it would leave his district unrepresented for the remainder of this Session. He thought that the failure of the Court, which should be held in February would be a greater inconvenience; and that if the nomination should be delayed it would not be acted upon by the Senate untill the extra Session. He said that Gurley was the only man friendly to the Administration who could be carried— Mr Clay took with him a Letter from the Spanish Minister Mr Tacon, and his reply, concerning Mr Salmon’s complaints against the Kirk family in Philadelphia— Mr Rush read to me, a Letter from him to the Chairman of the Committee of Ways and Means HR: recommending compensation to A. Dickins and his Sons for Services in carrying into effect the Act of last Session in favour of the Revolutionary Officers. Mr Rush took also part of my Manuscript on the Brevet Question— Coll. Gratiot read me two Authorities from Hough on Courts-Martial, concerning mutiny— A Court-Martial at West-Point have sentenced Cadet Jeremiah E Dargan to be shot for Mutiny, but recommended a commutation of dismission with disgrace— I approved the commutation, and disapproved the Sentence of Death— S. Reintzel came for the pardon of Reisner, Johnson Hellen introduced Stonestreet and Hall. Mrs Paradise was a mendicant— Evening, driven from my Chamber by the Cold— Ball at Genl. Porters’.
6. VI:15 Tuesday. Walk round Capitol Square—
Signed 6. Acts of Congress

Dr. Wallace came to renew his solicitation for an appointment, and to discourse, in speculations upon Natural History. Particularly upon the wonderful exhilarating effects of the Poison of the Rattlesnake, taken inwardly. Mr Connell was here this morning and again in the Evening. I told him I must decline giving any Instructions to Mr Wheaton our Charge d’Affaires in Denmark authorising him to compromise for indemnity to our citizens for spoliations in 1809. 10. Because such Instructions could not reach him till I shall be myself out of office, and they might be disavowed by my Successor— Connell spoke also of a claim of Mr La Grange a lawyer at Paris for services by him in relation to claims of our Citizens in France with regard to which I said I thought I must give the same answer. Major Nourse brought a Letter from General Scott to the Secretary of War enclosing 13. Interrogatories to the Adjutant General Coll. Jones, to be used before the Military Committees of the two Houses upon his Brevet Question— The Secy of War thought that Genl. Scott might address to the Adjutant General, or any other Officer any interrogatories that he thinks proper, but not officially through the War Department— Mr Lowrie, Secretary of the Senate brought me five Resolutions of that body; confirmations of appointments, advice to ratify the two Indian Treaties, and a Resolution that no paper sent by the Executive should be returned or delivered, but by an order of the Senate— Mr Iredell and Mr Maxwell, of the Committee of enrolled Bills, brought me six Bills which I signed— I returned to M. Dutton his manuscript— Captain Partridge, Chaplain Stewart, R. H. Lee and Mr Hassler were visitors— Mr Brent of Louisiana, recommended an immediate nomination of a District Judge, which I made by Message N 13 to the Senate, together with the name of H. G. Burton as Governor of the Territory of Arkansas.
7. IV. Wednesday— Ride— College and Capitol

Mr Patterson and Mr Thomas are Directors of the Baltimore and Ohio Rail-road. They are here to solicit of Congress to become subscribers for the United States to that undertaking— They have brought a new invented Car, to be used upon the Rail-way which they consider as greatly facilitating that mode of transportation and it is deposited at the Capitol for inspection— Invented by a Mr Weenan of N. Jersey— Coll. Crowell brought me copies of his Letter and of the opinion of Walter Jones, upon the claim of the Creek Indians to the balance of the sum appropriated by Treaty to indemnify Citizens of Georgia, for old depredations— He wished these papers to be communicated to the House of Representatives, upon a Call which he expected would be brought to me this day— General M’Arthur, Mr Vance, Member of the House from Ohio, Mr Mason and Dr. Reynolds called on a visit together— Mr Rush brought back the part of my Manuscript which he had taken and suggested a very few alterations— There is yet a question whether I shall have it printed or not— Mr Rush mentioned the application to him of Mr Washington one of the Clerks in the Department for extra pay— and his great dissatisfaction at its being refused— Mr Brent spoke of the circular Letter to be addressed to the members of the Senate of the United States, concerning an extra Session of that body on the fourth of March next— I desired him to have those Letters despatched immediately.— Mr Sullivan paid me a visit— He is now engaged as an Engineer on the Baltimore Railroad, and told me that he was the person who had procured for them the new invented waggon which is now at the Capitol for inspection— I sent Message to the Senate N. 14. with Army Nominations, and of a Collector at Portland, Maine—and to the House N. 6. a Report from the Secretary of State, and Correspondence with the Spanish Government upon claims. The Death of Mrs Rachel Jackson at Nashville, suddenly, on the 22d. of last Month is confirmed— There was an evening party at Mr Clay’s attended by part of my family.
8. V:30. Thursday.— Walk to the Capitol—

There was a heavy rain which continued the whole day, and reduced my number of visitors, so that I should have had an unusual position of leisure; but I was still absorbed in occupation. Major Nourse brought me part of the copy of my observations upon Brevet Rank— I sent for Mr. Force and gave him some sheets of the first part of it— He said it would take a fortnight of time to print it, and I am obliged to precipitate the work— The Military Committee of the Senate have already reported against the petition of General Scott’s Memorial; but the Report and the Memorial have been laid on the table, on the motion of Mr Tyler of Virginia.— The Memorial, is in substance a heavy charge against me of gross and wanton abuse of power to the oppression and dishonour of the Memorialist. I took it up this day, and began to write some observations upon it, with a view to give them to General Porter for the preparation of his answer to the reference from the Military Committee of the House of Representatives. Mr Connell called upon me, having postponed his departure for Philadelphia till to-morrow— He left with me an Album, in which he had written at sundry times and places lessons of moral Instruction to his Son, and in which he requested me to write some lines— I accordingly wrote on one of its blank pages my paraphrase from the golden verses of Pythagoras. Notwithstanding the rain I walked before dinner up to the Capitol, and there found Mr Elgar who shewed me the new invented railway waggon— It is a Platform upon four wheels, and the ends of the two axles are loosely suspended on the inward periphery of a small revolving wheel, like a Scale beam upon an agate— It reduces the friction to its minimum, and the car with a load of several hundred pounds moves as if by instinct. Once set in motion upon the level, it proceeds as if by the mere vis inertiae— Much of the evening was employed in signing Landgrants—
9. V:15. Friday. Dinner party— Walk

Mr Clay mentioned the recent occurrence of which Baron Stackelberg the Swedish Charge d’Affaires had said something to me, on New-Years day— Captain Turner of the US Sloop of War Erie, cut out from the Harbour of the Island of St. Bartholomew a Privateer called the Federal; which was under the Buenos-Ayrean flag— It appears that she had taken property out from a vessel of the United States, as being Spanish property— Captain Turner demanded of the authorities of the Island, that the privateer her Captain and crew should be delivered up to him, as piratical aggressors upon the property of Citizens of the United States— The Officers of the Island declined giving them up—on which Turner cut the vessel out— The authorities of the Island have made a complaint against Turner, through a Memorial by Baron Stackelberg to the Secretary of State. Mr Clay answered that enquiry would be made, and wrote for that purpose to the Secretary of the Navy— We agreed that the act of Captn Turner must be disavowed, but I thought the disavowal should be accompanied with an earnest complaint against the authorities of the Island, for harbouring this piratical vessel— The whole subject must be turned over to our Successors— Mr Clay spoke of my nomination of H. G. Burton as Governor of Arkansas, as unexpected. I told him my reasons for making it— Mr Brent brought some Letters and despatches from Mr Ratcliff Consul at Lima— Mr Silsbee introduced Mr Williams of Newbury-Port— Nathan Sergent brought a Letter from General Porter and solicits a place. N. Frye took away the papers relating to the Accounts of T. J. Hellen— Mr Wirt spoke of Genl Porter’s having asked his opinion upon a claim for Salary as Commissioner under the 6th. and 7th. Articles of the Treaty of Ghent— I had decided against it in the case of C. P. Van Ness.— Major Nourse brought me the remainder of my Manuscript upon Brevet-rank. We had a dinner party— S. C. Allen, Bouligny, Buckner, E. F. Chambers, D. Chase, Conner, J. Davenport— T. and Mrs Fort, Hassler Hinds, Jennings, R. and Mrs Keese, Cruger, Legarè, W. M’Coy and Miss, M’Intire, Merwin, T. R. Mitchell, Partridge, Jos. and Mrs Richardson, Ruggles, Sevier, W. Smith, James and Mrs Smith, Strong. Taliaferro, Tucker, Vinton, G. C. and Mrs Washington and Wolf— T. Whipple came late and went away—
10. V. Saturday.

Mr White came with a subscription paper for a History of the Greek Revolution, by Dr Howe who has been a Surgeon in their Service. I declined subscribing but said I might take a copy of the book when published— I had such a History already by Comstock. Mr Gurley a member of the House of Representatives from Louisiana introduced a Mr Bird of that State. Mr Dorsey of Maryland came with his Son, and Mr M’Lane a Senator from Delaware with a Mr Black of that State— The Secretary of War brought several papers relating to General Gaines, Governor Cass and Coll. Leavenworth— Those of Gaine’s concern a claim for payment of a tavern Bill at Gadsby’s in this City, while he was here last Spring after the death of General Brown— The Quarter Master disallows the Account, and General Gaines appeals to the Secretary of War— His Letter is in an Angry and overbearing temper— General Porter left it with me— The claim of Governor Cass is for compensation as Superintendant of Indian Affairs, for several years— It is for a Commission of 2 1/2 per Cent upon disbursements which he proposes to commute for a sum of 1500 dollars a year—for seven years— Coll Leavenworth is weary of the army and now offers himself as a Candidate to be Governor of the proposed new territory of Huron— But that appointment will be made by the next Administration— General Porter spoke also of his own claim for compensation as Commissioner under the 6th. and 7th. Articles of the Treaty of Ghent which he requested me and which I promised to reconsider— I gave him my observations upon General Scott’s Memorial to Congress requesting him to make such use of them as he thinks proper on answering the reference to him of the Memorial by the Military Committee of the House of Representatives— We had some conversation upon the proposal for altering the organization of the army; but not definitive— Mr Gilmer a Member of the House of Representatives from Georgia, recommended a Mr Olin, a Clergyman, to be the Secretary of the Legation to London. Frederick Lewis is a black man, going to the Settlement at Liberia—
11. V:45. Sunday.

Heard Mr Bigelow at the Unitarian Church from Genesis 3.17. [“]And unto Adam he said, Because thou hast hearkened unto the voice of thy wife, and hast eaten of the tree, of which I commanded thee, saying, Thou shalt not eat of it: cursed is the ground for thy sake; in sorrow shalt thou eat of it all the days of thy life; 18 Thorns also and thistles shall it bring forth to thee; and thou shalt eat the herb of the field; 19 In the sweat of thy face shalt thou eat bread, till thou return into the ground: for out of it wast thou taken: for dust thou art, and unto dust shalt thou return”— An argumentative and controversial discourse upon the fall of our first Parents; in refutation of the Calvinistic doctrines on this subject— The Calvinists admit that these doctrines cannot stand the test of human reason, but say they must be received as Articles of faith— The imputation of guilt upon the whole race of Adam for his transgression is difficult to be reconciled to our ideas of Justice; but the sentence of death passed upon him has certainly been extended to all his posterity— Mr Bigelow promised to consider the subject again hereafter— I called to see Mr Southard who is dangerously ill, but he was asleep— I saw at his house Mr Stewart the Missionary Clergyman— In the afternoon at St. John’s Church Mr Hawley read the abridged evening Service for the first Sunday after the Epiphany, and Mr Johns preached from 2. Kings 20–1. the latter part of the verse— “Thus saith the Lord, Set thine house in order; for those shalt die, and not live.” May I without superstition consider this as a third warning? And if so, may I pray to be spared to set my House in order, till after I shall be released from the burden of my public duties? The Sermon of Mr Johns was deeply impressive, and closed with a solemn address to every individual of his Hearers which I ought to lay to heart— May it not be lost upon me— Mr Bailey and Coll. Dwight of Massachusetts and Mr P Sprague of Maine, dined with me, and we had much convivial conversation after dinner— I was over-talkative, and in a flow of Spirits contrasted with the solemnity of feeling inspired by the exercises of the day. Mr Everett called in the Evening, and gave me a pamphlet copy of the Address of H. G. Otis Mayor of Boston in Faneuil-Hall last Monday—
12. IV. Monday— Potowmac frozen over—

Mr Condict a Member of the House of Representatives from New-Jersey introduced two brothers of the name of Vale, and another person from that State.— Mr Williams a Senator from Mississippi came with a friend from that State, and Mr Pearce Member from Rhode-Island, was accompanied by Mr Whipple a lawyer from Providence; here to attend the Session of the Supreme Court of the United States which commenced this day— Only two of the judges however, Washington and Story attended— Judge Cranch came with a Mr Williams now from South-Carolina, an applicant for the appointment of Superintendent of the Penitentiary— An Office not yet created— Mr Williams went from Maryland to South-Carolina, where he is employed at the College, but whence he is very anxious to return— I went to the topographical Office at the War Department, where I found Mr Hassler measuring the french Metres and the English Ell and Yard from the Department of State—upon Troughton’s scale— I remained about an hour while he was observing; but found it too cold and his operations too slow to stay till the end— Thence I went over to Mr Southard’s house where he was confined to his bed chamber, as he has been ever since New-Year’s day. He has been very ill with a lingering daily fever, but was this day better— I had met at my door as I was going out, Mr Stewart the Missionary Clergyman, who had a note from him to me, asking directions from the President with regard to Presents to be given to the Chiefs at the Sandwich Islands— He wanted from 120 to 150 dollars worth for that purpose— I desired him to make the application in writing and send it to the Department of State; and said I would give directions, that the money should be supplied from the contingent fund of expenses of foreign Intercourse. I met at Mr Southard’s Mr Taliaferro of Virginia who mentioned that Mr Bateman of New-Jersey had resigned his Seat in the Senate, and that probably Mr Southard would be elected in his place— Mr Webster took his Seat in the Senate this day. Finished the preface to my Brevet-Observations.
13. VI. Tuesday— Snow— Walk round Capitol Square.
Signed 30 Blank Patents—and 50 Mediterranean Passports— Also a Pardon to Ann sentenced to receive 30 stripes for larceny—

The cold weather and snowy atmosphere have brought with them a rhumatic and feverish pain in the head which partly disabled me this day— General Smith, Senator from Maryland introduced his nephew, a young Mr Nicholas of Kentucky Son of George Nicholas— Mr Whittlesey member of the House from Ohio came with Mr Holley a brother of the late President of Transylvania University, and a Mr Hunt— Mr Hendricks, a Senator from Indiana, and Mr Buckner, a member of the House from Kentucky came to recommend a Mr Floyd of Florida, as Collector of a newly established Port of Magnolia— Hendricks spoke also of a renomination of the Marshal of Indiana Vawter, but as his Commission expires on the 6th. of March, I shall leave that and all other nominations subsequent to the 3d. to my Successor— Mr Pearce, member of the House from R. Island introduced Mr King of that State— Mr Clay spoke of Webster’s adhesion to the new Administration, proclaimed somewhat ostentatiously by a puffing article in Walsh’s Gazette— General Porter had left here yesterday while I was out the draft of his answer to the Military Committee on the reference to him of Scott’s Memorial, and of Vance’s Resolutions. He called this day and took it back— We had some conversation upon it. I did not exactly concur with his views upon Vance’s Resolutions, but waved all objection to his sending them to the Committee— He proposed some alternations, and an addition to my remarks on Scott’s Memorial; to which I agreed— I asked him for the account of Gaines’s claim for payment of his Rooms last Winter at Gadsby’s— Lieutt. Coll. Wainwright of the Marines came to request that his Brevet of that rank, which is of 3. March 1827. should be dated back to 1823—which I told him could only be done by a new nomination to the Senate— But I promised to look into his papers and examine the question—
14. V:30— Wednesday— Snow. Rain 3d. Drawing-Room—

Mr Mallary a member of the House of Representatives from Vermont came with a very earnest recommendation from Mr Olin as Secretary of the Legation to Great Britain—the same person who had been recommended by Mr Gilmer of Georgia— Major Nourse came for a Report from the Secretary of War upon a Call from the House of Representatives, to refer it to the Treasury Department from which a Report must also be made in answer to the same Call— He sent me the disputed account of General Gaines and the rejection of it by the Quarter Master; and a request by Genl Jesup that it might be paid and charged to him— Coll. Leavenworth came, and desired a decision upon his application for the appointment of Governor of the Territory of Huron— But the Bill for constituting that Territory is yet before Congress— I read part of the recommendations of Coll. Leavenworth and told him I would answer him further to-morrow— Mr Rush read me a Letter from Mr Wirt asking for the employment of an accountant, in a cause lately tried before the U.S. Circuit Court at Baltimore and now coming up to the Supreme Court against the Bank of Somerset to which I agreed. Mr Rush took the remnant of my Manuscript on the Brevet to read and to peruse— I read to him my intended preface, to the first part of which he made some objection, though he approved it in the abstract— The three Judges of the Supreme Court now have visited me— None of the others have yet arrived— I sent for Mr Force to enquire The state of that part of my pamphlet of which he has the copy— He says it is nearly printed— He also told me that Fendall was writing a History of the present administration, which he should publish next Summer— I sent message to N. 2. to Congress—with the Annual Report from the Director of the Mint—and Message N. 14. to the Senate; supplementary to that of 9. December— This Evening was our third Drawing-Room— Well attended, although in foul weather— Mr Woodcock spoke to me of the Ex-Cadet Hughes, and asked to see me again in his behalf; to which I assented—
15— V:15— Thursday— Ride round College and Capitol

Mr Gilmer, brought me a paper signed by several members of Congress recommending Stephen Olin, as Secretary of the Legation at London; and renewed with great earnestness his own recommendation of him. Coll. Leavenworth came to take leave and for my decision upon his solicitations— One for an Appointment as Governor of the future Territory of Huron— The other for a Brevet of Brigadier General.— I told him there was no probability that it would devolve upon me to nominate the Governor of a Territory not yet established by Law— With regard to his claim to a Brevet he I would examine and consider it— I gave Mr Brent my decision upon the recommendation to Mercy, by the Court and Jury of Leland B. Rose, with a direction to lay it before the next President, and observed to him that the same must be done with the Papers relating to the proposed Negotiation with the Porte. Mr Rush returned me the remnant of my manuscript on the Brevet with several remarks and suggestions of very slight alterations— While he was here Mr Webster came in, and I had some conversation with him concerning Scott’s Memorial— General Macomb and Coll. Gratiot came together— Macomb left with me a list of the Officers of the Army now claiming Brevets; amounting to nineteen— But those of Coll. Gratiot are peculiar; as being Chief Engineer, he has now an Assistant, General Bernard of Superior Rank and Emoluments to his own. But I have some question of the right to nominate him for Brevet Rank—otherwise than for distinguished services— Lieutenant Coll. Wainwright of the Marine Corps— He procured also from the Navy Department several Opinions of the Attorney General concerning his case— The day was fine, and I took my ten Miles ride— Business multiplies upon me as I approach the term of my political life— This Evening I wrote a draft of a Letter from the Secretary of War to General Gaines, in answer to an offensive one from him of the 22d. of December last.
16. V:30. Friday.

Mr White the Delegate from Florida, came to recommend the appointment of Jesse H. Willis as Collector at the new Port of Magnolia— Mr Marvin of New York to recommend a Marshal for the Northern District of New-York, but the present Marshal H. W. Livingston is already re-appointed. Mr Anderson of Pennsylvania applied for a Midshipman’s warrant for his Son. Mr Clay said he had mentioned to Mr Webster Lyman’s libel, and my publication of 21. October—that Webster professed to have no unfriendly feeling to me: but that he seemed to regret his having prosecuted Lyman— Mr Clay had prepared an Instruction to Mr Brown, who is to return from his Mission to France in May, directing him to leave the Affairs of the Mission to J. A. Smith as Chargé d’Affaires—but I told him, I thought it best to have leave to the succeeding Administration to instruct him. Mr Lowrie Secretary of the Senate brought me a Resolution of that body confirming several appointments. General Porter was here, and I gave him the draft of an answer to General Gaines’s Letter of 22. December—and I asked him for copies of all the papers relating to the case— Mr Rush read a Letter from Judge Cranch respecting the expenses of repairs upon the Court-room in the City Hall— I gave Mr Wirt the remainder of my Manuscript on the Brevet, and read to him the preface asking his advice concerning the publication— He sent the manuscript back in the Evening with a Letter of strong objection to its severity. General Parker came to say he hoped Coll. Abert would be stationed at the Post occupied by Coll. Roberdeau till his decease— Lewis Williams came to recommend John S. Shepard as Collector of the new Port of Magnolia— Fendall introduced Mr Allen and his Son— R Peters spoke to me of a Letter from his father to T. Pickering— We had company to dine. Alexander, Barker, Barney, Barringer, I. C. Bates, D. Brent, Daniel, De Graff, Dickerson, Johns and Mrs Johnston & Mrs. Lowrie, Martin, Marvin, Maxwell, Peters, Varnum, Webster, Whipple Whittlesey, Lewis Williams, James Wilson and Wood— With our own family of eight. John’s wife does not yet leave her chamber.
17. V. Saturday.

General Van Rensselaer called to recommend several persons for appointments. Colonel Little to introduce three of his friends— I sent for Force and requested him to stop the impression of the pamphlet upon Brevet rank, as I had concluded not to publish it for the present— I desired him to return me the manuscript, and send me a bill for the work done upon it, as far as he had gone, which I promised to pay. Coll. Crowell came to request that I would immediately send to the House of Representatives, his Letter to me, with Walter Jones’s opinion, upon the right of the Creek Indians, to a balance of appropriations, upon which Citizens of Georgia have also claims. I sent for a Report from the Secretary of War on the Resolution of the House of Representatives, and sent the Report together with Crowell’s Letter to me, and W. Jones’s opinion, with Message to H.R.U.S. N. 7. General D. Parker to ask me to renominate Callender Irvine as Commissary General of purchases— These affairs detained me so that in attending the funeral of Lt. Coll. Isaac Roberdeau, I arrived at his house just after the procession had left it— I joined however in the procession of Carriages, and followed it to the burying ground— Mr Seymour Senator from Vermont, told me that the Majority of the Judiciary Committee of the Senate had determined to report against acting upon any nominations at this Session, unless in cases of special necessity— Seymour himself and Webster being the minority of the Committee against the Resolution. Seymour recommended also Mr Olin, for the appointment of Secretary of Legation to London— Mr Clay returned me the preface to my Observations upon the Brevet, with commendation— But I told him I had concluded not to publish them— General Porter urged me again with regard to his claim for Salary as Commissioner under the 6th. and 7th. Article of the Treaty of Ghent— And I agreed to receive and consider an opinion of the Attorney General on the subject. I called at Mr Southard’s, he being still confined to his chamber— His election as Senator from New-Jersey is likely to fail, by their starting against him the question of inhabitancy, as they did against Mr Bailey.
18. VI— Sunday— Snow-Storm—

The Heaviest Snow Storm that I recollect to have witnessed here since March 1809. It began last Night and continued through this day till within an hour of Sunset when it cleared off and the Sun went down in a clear sky— I went to the second Presbyterian Church where I found six or eight persons assembled; but no Minister— I then went to St. John’s Church which was also shut up; and I then returned home and read the 17th. 18th. 19th. and 20th. Chapters of Jeremiah— Also the 15th. and 16th. Chapters of the second Book of Samuel and the 7th. Psalm— I signed several hundred Land Patents and in the Evening began a Letter to my Son George— I reflected further upon my determination to suppress my observations upon Brevet-rank— I have put too much temper in them; and instead of punishing Gaines and Scott must begin by punishing myself— They have provoked me to anger; but I have to remember the injunction “be ye angry and sin not.” There is so much of sarcastic bitterness and indignation in what I have written, that I come under suspicion of mistaking my resentment for patriotism— I lose two Months of painful labour, and perhaps the usefulness of a cool discussion upon an important subject of military administration. But I teach myself the lesson of treating the subject in a different manner, and perhaps spare myself some additional and unnecessary enmities— Of these I have already more than enough— Part of the Solitude of this day was occupied in the anticipation of that condition upon which I am about to enter— In fervent prayer that my heart and temper maybe accommodated to it. That I may be provided in it with useful and profitable occupation, engaging so much of my thoughts and feelings that my mind may not be left to corrode itself— I shall need a double portion of discretion, and of fortitude— “O Lord my God, in this do I put my trust: save me from all them that persecute me, and deliver me.”
“The Lord shall judge the People: judge me O Lord, according to my righteousness, and according to mine integrity that is in me. My defence is of God, which saveth the upright in heart”— Psalm 7.
19. VI— Monday,

Mr Fendall called upon me this Morning and mentioned his design of publishing a History of the present Administration. He read to me a Prospectus which he had prepared of the work, but said that upon further reflection he inclined to adopt a different plan, less marked with the character of a partizan, which I approved— I observed to him that impartiality was the Law of History, and that as the correctness of the popular voice at the recent election, was to be tested by time and experience, it would not be wise or just to assume before hand that it was all error and delusion— We had much desultory Conversation upon the manner in which the History should be written, and I mentioned to him the projects floating in my own mind of writing Memoirs of my fathers life and my own—perhaps even a History of the United States, from the formation of their Confederacy— I told him also that his Cousin Richard Henry Lee had informed me that he had the intention of writing a History of the present Administration, and he spoke of a Mr Rogers of New-York, who had expressed a similar design— Mr Jackson is an applicant for Office, who removed from North-Carolina to this place for that purpose, and now asked me to return him his Letters of recommendation— They are to be looked up— Todd wished my subscription to the publication of a Translation of Malte-Brun’s Geography, but I declined— Mr Cheves paid me a morning visit— Major Nourse brought a communication from the Seneca Indians complaining of Red Jacket: and an application for the permission to sell Indian reserved lands in Ohio— I gave him several Letters of General Scott to be copied— Mr Brent came concerning an application from the Secretary of the Navy for a sum of 150 dollars from the fund for the contingent expenses of foreign intercourse, to make presents to Chiefs at the Sandwich Islands— I gave it to Mr Brent, with my order upon it for the money— Linsey was a man from New-York apparently insane who said he had purchased Lands in Virginia sold for payment of the direct tax; but which he had lost because they had already been sold before— He had applied to Congress in vain; and said he now came to me because I had one third as much power as Congress—
20. V:45. Tuesday.

Dr. Wallace called upon me, and we had a long conversation upon fire and Water, Rain and Snow; but especially upon Water, which he said was composed of three of the most combustible elements in Nature—Oxygen, Hydrogen, and Electricity— He referred all to the glory of God—and I read to him the first verse of the 19th. Psalm— Mr Force brought back the part of my manuscript upon the Brevet, which I had given him, and shewed me the pamphlet sent him by General Jackson, with the passionate and illiterate writing of his own upon a blank page of it— Dr Watkins came to ask for the papers of a Mr Salomons of New-York which were not to be found upon the files— Mrs Titcomb came with Mrs Sawyer, who lives next door to Mr Elliot, and with whom Mrs Titcomb is lodging— She is a widow, and came from Baltimore, to claim kindred with me, and assistance— She said her mother’s maiden name was Adams, daughter of Abraham Adams of Newbury, Massachusetts, and as she understood descended from Henry Adams, our first ancestor who came from England— But the Essex County Adams’s are not of the same family. Coll. Washington member of the House of Representatives from Maryland came to recommend Mr Willis as Collector of the new Port of Magnolia in Florida— Mr Clay spoke of his Letter to Mr Mullowny, our Consul at Tangier concerning our emancipation of the Moorish Prince Abdul Rahman, who is going to Liberia— General Parker called again to urge a nomination of Callender Irvine as Commissary General of purchases; who though specially named in the Office limitation Act, has from inadvertence never been renominated—and has now continued in Office eight years without renomination— I took it for consideration— Mr Everett introduced Mr Ward of Medford, Son of the late President of the State Bank at Boston— I walked before dinner round the Capitol Square, and employed the Evening upon fragments of business, public and private— Thomas J. Hellen returned this day to College—
21. VI:45 Wednesday—

Coll. Thomas came and took back his contract with the Government, one of this papers which had accidentally not been returned with the rest— He mentioned to me some conversations that he has held here with persons in pursuit of Office under the approaching Administration—Green and Broadhead from Boston, Simpson and Gardner of the Post-Office— He says Simpson told him that the Postmaster General is incumbered with an oppressive and increasing debt— That he is under pecuniary dependence upon the Bradley’s— That De Krafft has a pamphlet in preparation against them, which the Postmaster General will if possible suppress— That Petitions are in circulation to the next President urging him to turn out all Executive Officers, who have been long in service, on the principle of rotation; and that they are getting up charges of peculation against Clarke, the Clerk of the House of Representatives.— Mr Crowninshield called to say that his son Benjamin had been taken dangerously ill with a fever at Salem, and he feared he should be obliged to go home. He spoke to me, of the Deportment that I should hold towards my Successor, which I told him would depend upon his towards me— I should treat him with respect to his Station, but should make no advance to conciliation with him, as I had never wronged him, but much the reverse—but he had slandered me— He spoke also of the new federal struggle in Massachusetts, and the prospects of its success. Mr Threlkeld applied for a pardon to a boy Thomas Fowler convicted of stealing from him and sentenced to be whipped— I desired him to procure the recommendation of the District Attorney which he did, and I granted the pardon. Dr. Watkins brought me his pamphlet signed Tell, and Mr Brent W. B. Giles’s pamphlet upon Mr Clay’s Tariff Speech of 1824. General Porter brought voluminous papers relating to charges against B. F. Smith Agent with the Choctaw Indians; and read me a Letter to the Attorney General upon his Porter’s claim for Salary as Commissioner under the Ghent Treaty. Captain Partridge repeated an application for a Midshipman’s Warrant for a Greek boy from Scio whom he has taken under his protection. Messrs. Iredell, and Maxwell, of the Committee of enrolled Bills, brought me which I signed— I sent messages N. 3. to Congress—with two Indian Treaties— N. 16 to S.U.S. nominations. N. 8 to H.R.U.S—about John Baker—
22. VI. Thursday— Ride, College and Capitol

Mr Lowrie the Secretary of the Senate, brought me a Resolution concerning the recovery of debts of American Citizens in Mexico— Dr Wallace called and conversed again upon the phenomena of Nature and his wish to obtain an Office— He explained how he had got into uncomfortable dissensions with his neighbours. Mr Clark the Treasurer introduced to me two of his friends from Pennsylvania— Mr Long of the House of Representatives, one of his from North-Carolina; and Messrs. Clark and Chambers of Kentucky one of them from that State— Mr Clark desired to me to speak to the Postmaster General about the appointment of Maurice Langhorne definitively as Postmaster of Maysville— He says Mr M’lean told him that part of the Kentucky delegation had requested him to postpone the appointment— Mr Gorham introduced Mr Lowell of Boston, a son of Francis Lowell— Henry Dixon was Lieutenant of the Buenos-Ayrean Privateer Federal, cut out of the Harbour of St. Bartholomews, by the Boats of the U.S. Sloop of War, Lexington, Captain Turner— The Officers of the Federal were left on Shore, and Dixon has found his way here. He is a native of New-York, and said all the Officers of the Federal were citizens of the United States— He told me he had been three years in the service of Buenos-Ayres, but his Commission which he shewed me was dated last September— I told him the whole case must be tried at Law— Mr Frye spoke to me in behalf of Coll. Abert, to supply the place of the late Coll. Roberdeau at the topographical bureau of the War Department— I sent for General Macomb, and consulted with him upon the order I propose to issue respecting the Settlement of Accounts of Army Officers; in which upon his advice I made a slight alteration. Mr Hooe is an applicant for an appointment— He says Mr Monroe positively promised to give him one but did not; and he shewed me many recommendations in his favour— Mr Clay is again unwell; confined to his bed— His son Thomas is said to be in prison at Philadelphia—
23. VI. Friday.— Dinner party— Walk round Capitol Square—

Mr Tracy, a member of the House of Representatives from the Western part of New-York came to enquire how an investigation could be had of the conduct of a man named Jewett keeper of a Light House at Fort Niagara, and also keeper of the Fort, implicated in the murder of Morgan— I told him the charges must be made in writing—then communicated to Jewett—with a call for his answer to them—and if that should not prove a satisfactory justification of his conduct then a person or persons are appointed as Commissioners to investigate the case by testimony upon oath for and against him; upon whose Report he would be retained in or removed from Office— Mr Wright member of the House of Representatives from Ohio, introduced his two Sons, and Mr Kane, a Senator from Illinois, his brother, from New-York— Mr Lowrie, the Secretary of the Senate, brought me four Resolutions of that body confirming nominations, but leaving all those that are to commence about the last of February and beginning of March not acted upon— The Judge of the Supreme Court—the District Judges of Pennsylvania, Ohio, and Louisiana, and C. Hughes as Minister to the Netherlands are also postponed— Mr Silsbee called and mentioned that Mr Crowninshield left the City yesterday morning to return home— Mr Blake was here, having been detained some days by a fever at New-York. He is convalescent, but looks very ill— Captain Beard came to ask the return of his recommendatory papers; and bitterly to complain that he had not been nominated for the Agency to the Caddo Indians— He said the President had been imposed upon, for that Dr. Sibley was 75. and very infirm— We had company to dine— J Chandler M. S. C. and Mrs Clarke, Davis, Forward, Hodges, Kane and his brother, Locke, Lowell, W. M’lean, Mather, Maynard, Commodore and Mrs Patterson, Plant, Prince, P. B. and Mrs Porter, Ripley, Storrs and his brother Wales, Ward of N.Y. Ward of Medford, Wright, and his two Sons—with our own family 36 at table— Mr Clay, Mr Rush, and Mr Southard—with their Ladies were invited, but were all three confined to their houses by severe illness—
24. V:15. Saturday— Ride. College and Post-Office

Mr White of Florida, introduced Mr Willis, who is one of the Candidates for the appointment of Collector of the new Port of Magnolia, and who left with me a budget of recommendatory Letters— Mr Gilmer and Dr Fort of Georgia came to repeat the application in behalf of Mr Olin for the appointment of Secretary of Legation at London; but they could say nothing positive with regard to the state of his health. Mr Martin, member of the House from S.C. introduced Mr Gilliston— Tryon was a book pedlar of whom I have several times purchased small tracts— He had one this day entitled White Lies which I declined taking, telling him I had quite enough of the black lies now in circulation, with which he was much diverted. Nourse brought me a member of Commissions of Militia Officers to sign. Mr Hendricks spoke again of locations of reserved lands interfering with a grant to the State of Indiana for a Canal— Mr Wever resigned his Office of Superintendant of the National Road, and recommended his assistant in his place— Judge Tucker member of the House from New-Jersey introduced Mr Mullens and Mr Hodges of Massachusetts, his friend of New-Bedford— Mr. Bell, Senator from New-Hampshire recommended Mr Waldron for an appointment of purser in the Navy. W. Tharp came again with a budget of papers, asking a decision upon what I have already many times decided—but I took his papers— Brower and Dodd came merely on a visit of curiosity— I read to Mr Blake the Letter of the Confederates and my answer. He told me remarkable anecdotes of S. Dexter and of Jonathan Simpson— Mr Pearce of Rhode-Island recommended again his friend Cahoone for a Purser’s appointment. Mr Brent brought a Note from Mr Vaughan asking an Audience to deliver a Letter from the king of England, announcing the death of his Sister the Queen of Wurtemberg— T. J. Hellen here from the College—
25. VI:15. Sunday.

I should have mentioned yesterday that Dr Lovell came yesterday with a subscription paper to me, for building a new Church for the second Presbyterian Church, who have recently settled Mr Campbell— He did not sufficiently explain to me why they should undertake this, and I declined subscribing; but said I would not make any difficulty with them about it— I heard this morning Mr Bigelow, from Matthew 27.22. [“]Pilate saith unto them, What shall I do then with Jesus which is called Christ? They all say unto him, let him be crucified— 23. And the Governor said, Why, what evil hath he done? But they cried out the more, saying, let him be crucified.”— This discourse upon the death of Christ was not equal to the subject, and not among the happiest of Mr Bigelow’s efforts— After the morning service I called on Mr Southard, Mr Clay, and at Mr Rush’s House— They are all three confined by Indisposition— Mr Southard, convalescent— Mr Clay, recovering, but looking very sick— Mr Rush so ill; that I could not see him— Mrs Rush came down, and said he had a severe fever. Mr Clay mentioned to me that Mr West had also been taken suddenly ill, last Evening— On my return home, Mr Asbury Dickins called, and told me that it would be necessary to use a fac-simile for the signature of Mr Rush.— I consented, as the precedent was settled in the case of Mr Crawford, and there was an opinion of the Attorney General in favour of its legality— I gave Mr Dickins a packet of pamphlets that I had received from France for the Columbian Institute— I attended the afternoon service at St. John’s Church. Mr Hawley read the abridged Evening service for the third Sunday after the epiphany; and preached a short Sermon, from Revelation 2.7. “To him that overcometh will I give to eat of the tree of life, which is in the midst of the paradise of God.” This is the tree mentioned in Genesis 3.23—and is proved by this passage to be an allegorical tree— Judge Story, Mr Sergeant and Mr Sprague dined with us.— I gave to Mr Sprague, the circular to the Senators, convening them to meet in extra Session, the fourth of March next— Mrs Smith was confined by illness to her bed, but my wife, and my Son John’s wife dined with us— I wrote in the Evening in the bed-chamber, the fire being extinct in my own—
26. V. Monday— Walk round Capitol Square

Dr Sewall introduced Professor Wells of Bowdoin College— Dr Todsen has returned from an expedition of exploring Indians westward of the Mississippi. Mr Turner, Collector of Georgetown came to inform me that he had received the Bust of Genl La Fayette, sent by from France, intended for Congress, and forwarded by Mr Bernard from New-York. I desired Mr. Turner to give notice to the Secretary of the Senate, and the Clerk of the House of Representatives— Mr Dickins called to say that Mr Rush was very ill, and I received a note from Dr Sim saying that he would certainly not be able to attend to business for at least a week— I went to see him after first calling upon Mr Southard, and asking if he could undertake to act as Secretary of the Treasury at least for a few days, to which he consented— I found Mr Rush very ill in bed with a fever, and Mrs Rush much alarmed. Dickins was there. Returning home I called upon Mr Clay; and again upon Mr Southard, to whom Mr Dickins is to take from day to day. The papers to be signed— I found on reaching home, Mr Vaughan, the British Minister here; he delivered to me the Letter from the King, announcing the death of his Sister the Queen Dowager of Wurtemberg. With the usual form of condolence I desired Mr Vaughan to assure his Government of the continued desire of the United States to cherish the most cordial harmony in their relations with Great-Britain. Mr Long and Mr Barringer, members of the House from North-Carolina introduced Mr Peck who left with me a Letter merely complimentary. Captain Beard took his papers. Genl. Thornton came to solicit the appointment of Walter Jones as Major General in place of W. Smith, resigned— Mr Hassler brought me a Report of his measurement of the Platine Metre and English Yard and Ell, upon Troughton’s Scale-beam— I asked Mr Brent to pay him 75 dollars for the service— Genl Porter came with Mr Shriver, who brought a Report and two plans of the continuation of the Cumberland Road to Vandalia— General Devereux was a transient Visitor— Mr Frye came to plead for a Clerk in the Paymaster General’s Office named Rich. Mr Bailey spent part of the Evening with me—
27. VI:15. Tuesday.— Walk round Capitol Square

I sent yesterday Messages—to Congress N. 4. with copies of the Commercial Convention and additional Article with the free Hanseatic Republics— To the Senate, N. 17. with nominations—and to the House of Representatives N. 9. with Reports from the Secretary of War and documents in answer to two Calls from the House, for the Instructions and the Journal of the Commissioners who made the Treaty of Indian Springs in 1821. with the Creek Indians— Mr. Bates member of the House of Representatives from Missouri, came for my decision, upon an appeal from the Commissioner of the General Land-Office, concerning his right to a Land Patent— Mr Bates had left the papers with me, at the close of the last Session of Congress— I had given no decision upon them, and have now to look them up and examine them again. General Parker called with a Letter from Callender Irvine, Commissary General of purchases— By some inadvertence he has not been nominated for re-appointment under the four years Law—and has now served two terms, eight years without re-appointment— Morning visit from Mr Coxe and Mr Mifflin of Philadelphia— I sent for Coll. Jones, Adjutant General, and shewed him the draft of a Regulation—forbidding the accounting Officers, from receiving the certificates of Officers of the Army as Evidence of their claims to extra pay, emoluments or allowance; but he thought it would restrict them too much—such certificates having been heretofore received in many cases—and frequently no other evidence being in their power— I desired Coll. Jones to take my draft of Regulations and shape it in such manner as might answer my purpose, without introducing restrictions too severe— Mr Brent from the Department of State brought me a despatch from W. Tudor Charge d’Affaires at Rio de Janeiro announcing that he expected in two days to sign a commercial Treaty; and asking permission to return to the United States for his health—which permission I desired Mr Brent to transmit to him as soon as possible— I signed 77 Commissions of Officers in the Militia of the District of Columbia— Rainy walk round the Square—
28. VI:15. Wednesday. Last Drawing Room.

Mr White of Florida came to urge again the appointment of Jesse H. Willis as Collector at the new Port of Magnolia— Mr Reed member of the House from Massachusetts to obtain the release from prison of Obed Baxter; for which I signed an order— I sent for Mr M’lean the Postmaster General, and requested him to issue definitively the Commission to Maurice Langhorne as Postmaster at Maysville; which he said he would do— He told me that some of the members from Kentucky had asked him to postpone the forwarding of the Commission— Judge Hay paid me a morning visit— He is here with his wife, and their daughter Hortensia— Mr Holmes, returned again as a Senator from the State of Maine was here; and spoke of the base intrigue to supplant C. Hughes, as Minister to the Netherlands and thrusting Preble into his place— Mr Chambers Senator from Maryland asked information concerning the Executive Appointments four years since, and at the Commencement of Mr Jefferson’s Administration. The proposition before the Senate is to postpone acting at all, upon all of the important nominations of the present Session; which I observed was an abdication of power and of duty by the Senate, to accumulate the same upon the next President— General Porter shewed me his draft of an answer to a proposed enquiry by the House concerning the effect of supplying ardent Spirits to the Soldiers of the army. I told him I thought it would be useless, and I feared worse, to attempt the prohibition of it— Mr Dinsmoor renewed his application for a per diem allowance while he has been detained here in settling his Accounts— I desired him to state his claim in writing— Mr Butman member of the House from Maine recommended a Mr Carr for an Appointment of Purser in the Navy— Mr Mallary, member from Vermont came to urge the appointment of N. Fosdick as Marshall of the Northern District New-York— But Livingston was already re-appointed. Coll. R. Jones brought me to sign, a Commission for Walter Jones as Major-General of the Militia in the District of Columbia. We had our last Drawing Room and a Supper— Company much crowded. Dancing till Midnight— Military Committee H.R.U.S. reported against Scotts petition—
29. VII:15. Thursday.— Walk round Capitol Square—

Mr Vance of the Military Committee of the House of Representatives told me last Evening that he should this day Report a Bill to abolish the Office of Major General, and all Brevets in time of Peace— I asked General Macomb to call upon me to-morrow Morning, that is, this day, and he came— I told him what Genl. Vance had said to me, and advised him if he had friends in Congress, disposed to sustain him to apprize them of the object of this movement— He said he had from motives of delicacy abstained from conversation with members of Congress, but that he would speak to his friend Governor Cass, who would see any members to whom it might be useful to give explanations— Mr Burnett, Senator from the State of Ohio said he came to me on an unpleasant subject— He had a Letter from Charles Hammond stating that Mr Doddridge of Virginia had written to me—that he Mr Burnett had said that the elder Adams by the appointment of John Marshall as Chief Justice had entailed a curse upon the Country, and that if I should have the opportunity to appoint Daniel Webster as Marshall’s Successor, it would be a still greater curse— He said there were not two men in the world for whom he had a greater veneration than for Chief Justice Marshall and Mr Webster— I said Mr Hammond had been misinformed— Mr Doddridge, whom I scarcely knew, had written to me, that he had heard Mr Burnet had expressed disapprobation of the decisions of the Supreme Court of the United States, with reference to questions involving the State authorities— He had not named Mr Webster— Mr Burnett said he had expressed the opinion that perhaps the decisions of the Supreme Court had sometimes encroached upon the State-Rights— Mr Anderson the Comptroller, brought an account of Coll. Ogden, for contingencies of the Slave Commission, which I approved. Mr Southard and Dickens had business from the Treasury and Navy Departments— Mr Hassler wished for an appointment of his Son, in the civil engineering service— Coll. Jones brought me the Commission of Walter Jones as Major General of the District Militia, which I signed— Mr Derrick brought a Letter of recall to W. Tudor which I approved— Sent message to S.U. S. N. 18— Nominations— And a Letter to the President of the Senate, with one from the Sculptor David to me—
30. VI. Friday—

Mr Linsay came with a recommendation to charitable contributions from Mr Bigelow, the Minister of the Unitarian Church— Linsay is about returning home to the State of New-York. Mr Lewis was a visitor from Philadelphia— Mr Derrick from the Department of State, brought me a draft of a Letter of Instruction, to Mr Barbour, complaining of three several cases of Impressment by British Naval Officers of American Seamen, within the last three years, which I approved. General Porter, brought a new draft of his answer to the reference of a Regulation for enquiring into the expediency of prohibiting the use of ardent Spirits by the Soldiers of the Army. It differed from the former draft; adopting the idea that I had suggested, that such a regulation would degrade the character of the Army, without producing any reformation of intemperance— Vices which affect the rights of others may be restrained by Law and regulation— Those of which the operation is confined to the Offender himself can be controuled by others only by abridging personal Liberty. I gave Genl. Porter the Letter from Mr Williams of Detroit to Genl. Van Rensselaer which speaks of the dissatisfaction of the Winebago Indians who were lately here—censoriously of the general management of Indian Affairs, and with manifestation of a keen appetite in the winter to be employed as an Indian Agent himself. Genl. Porter said he would converse with Governor Cass upon the subject— I sent message N. 10 to the House of Representatives—a Report from the Secretary of War, and documents concerning the compact of 1802 with Georgia, and the Cherokee Indians— We had company to dine. The last entertainment of my political Life— And given to the Judges of the Supreme Court of the United States— The company were D. D. Barnard and Mrs J Barrell, G. Blake, W. T. Carroll, R. S. Coxe, W. Cranch, C. E. Dudley, G. Duvall, Mrs Everett, N. Frye, G. Hay, Mrs and Miss, J. Holmes, W. Jones, B. L. Lear, Jos. M. Lewis, John Marshall, S. Mifflin, R. Peters, T. Ringgold, J. Sergeant. Jos. Story, T. Swann. B. Thruston. and B. Washington. Judge and Mrs Thompson, just arrived, sent an excuse—
31. V:45. Saturday. Snow the whole day—

Mr Wyman is a Citizen of Boston, a Leather dresser, originally of Medford, who has come hither at this Season to obtain for one of his Sons an appointment as a Cadet at West-Point— He brought me a Letter from Mr Webster; and told me he had educated his two older Sons at Cambridge University. Mr Sanford and Mr Dudley the two Senators from New-York paid me a morning visit— Coll. Jones the adjutant General of the Army brought me a Statement of the existing regulations respecting the claims of double-rations by brevetted Officers; and of the cases when their own certificates are admitted as evidence— I find upon examination of them that a regulation, excluding the receipt of their own declarations or certificates would be productive of great inconvenience— And as my own term of service is about expiring I concluded not to issue any new regulation— I received two days since, a Letter from three Ladies at Woodsfield, Ohio—requesting that Mrs Adams would name three female infants born there at a birth daughters of man named Mercer Sayre—himself one of the brothers also born at a birth in New-Jersey in the year 1793—and who, at the request of their Parents, President Washington then named Warren, Montgomery, and Mercer— Mrs Adams in her answer proposes that the first of the three girls should be named Martha Washington—the second Louisa Catherine, and the third, after the mother of the Children. I received also this morning from Baltimore the Lord’s prayer, very handsomely cut out in paper by a woman who says she has no hands. It snowed moderately part of the last Night and the whole of this day so that I was confined to the house— Before dinner I paced for half an hour the Entry that runs through the house lengthways. It is 36 paces or 160 feet long— I signed yesterday a pardon of John Young, a boy imprisoned for Stealing; and last Evening and this morning 7. Missouri Lead Mine Leases from 146 to 152 inclusive and 4 licences from 56 to 59 inclusive— Mrs Adams was unwell, confined the whole day to her bed— Mrs Smith was also confined to her chamber.

Day— My rising hour has ranged from IV to VII:15— The average being about V:30. and the changes regulated by the time of my retirement to bed which has varied from X:30 to I. A.M. which happened only once— The day of the last Drawing-room— My usual time of retirement is XI:30— Giving six hours to the bed— On rising I light my lamp, by the remnant of fire in the Bed-chamber—dress and repair to my Cabinet, where I make my fire and sit down to writing till between nine and ten— After Breakfast I read the morning National Intelligencer and Journal; and from X. A.M. to IV. P.M receive visitors, transact business with the Heads of Departments, and send Messages to one or both House of Congress— My riding on horseback has been interrupted almost the whole Month by the weather, and the Snow and the Ice—from four I walk an hour and a quarter till half past five— Dine, and pass one or two hours in the bed-chamber or Nursery. Then write again in my Cabinet till the time for repose— This routine has now became so habitual to me, that it forms part of the comfort of my existence, and I look forward with great solicitude to the time when it must be totally changed, I never go abroad unless to visit a sick friend. But a large dinner party, once a week, a Drawing room once a fortnight, occasional company of one two or three to dine with us in the family, and the daily visitors, eight or ten, sometimes twelve or fifteen keep me in constant intercourse with the world; and furnish constant employment the oppressiveness of which is much relieved by its variety. This is a happy condition of life, which within five weeks more must close— The prosperous condition of the Country takes from the load of public care, all its pain and almost all its weariness— My wife was exceedingly ill the first days of the Month, but has been in better health and Spirits, for the greater part of it— Mr and Mrs W. S. Smith—Thomas B. and Abigail S. Adams and Thomas J. Hellen have been with us all the Month— My Son John’s wife has kept her chamber till the last three or four days— Her daughter is close on two months Old, and is a fine thriving healthy child. With deep gratitude for the enjoyments yet indulged, let me not despair of the mercy with which they are to be withdrawn, and above all prepared to meet the change of fortune, about to befall me— “As ever in my task masters eye.”—
